snippet: The move, strenuously opposed by union workers and a majority of City Council members, aims to save the financially troubled city about $102 million a year.
abstract: Detroit will cut pay and toughen work rules for many of its unionized workers in move aimed at saving $102 million per year; decision, opposed by union leaders and a majority of the City Council, is perhaps the most significant result so far of Detroit's reluctant decision to allow formal state oversight of its finances.
lead_paragraph: The move, strenuously opposed by union workers and a majority of City Council members, aims to save the financially troubled city about $102 million a year.

headline.seo: Detroit to Cut City Workers’ Pay and Benefits
headline.main: Detroit Mayor Confirms Cuts to Workers’ Pay and Benefits
headline.print_headline: Detroit Mayor Confirms Cuts To Workers’ Pay and Benefits
